scenarioDescription:
The HD 109271 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 109271 is a star with 1.05 times the mass of the Sun, and NaN times its radius. It is located 182.23 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 7.3 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 109271 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 109271 system


HD 109271 b

HD 109271 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2013-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 109271 b is 17.172 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 109271 b is 4.310 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 109271 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HD 109271 c

HD 109271 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2013-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.20 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 109271 c is 24.168 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 109271 c is 5.270 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 109271 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system HD 109271, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the La Silla Observatory.
name: HD 109271 - System With 2 Exoplanets
